messages.title: Labour Invest in Education
messages.content: Ann Clwyd congratulated the Welsh Assembly and RCT Council on investing in education. New Labour government funding will benefit many local schools. Abercynon Primary School and Aberdare Community School were identified as specific cases. Key staged three tests performance has put former mining valleys at the top of the league table, something which favours the economy. The Assembly of South Wales agreed to allocate £500,000 towards appeal for more and better-trained headteachers for the local schools, according to existing plans. Cynon council expects Life-long learning conservative program so that it will favour all residents. The decision to introduce Homework compact supports and will help pupils to improve their skills in meeting these challenges is imperative.

messages.title: Danger: Conservative Landslide Possible
messages.content: We face unprecedented challenges in the next five years. Theresa May has refused to stand up for the general public. She has ignored Cynon Party, as she seeks for three years after we leave the EU. The aims are clear. The same was true when there was a landslide in 1983, it changed the history resulting in poor housing with cuts in welfare. This will devastate our communities in the same way, so we need hope and investment, not devastation and disdain.

messages.title: Small Business Under Attack
messages.content: Small business under siege in the Cynon Valley, says Ann Clwyd. Creative Industries and under Labour promises to revitalise the local economy. In response to the Communities’ innovation fund, she wishes to develop new start-ups and reverse the increasing threat from chain stores, promoting local businesses and locally produced goods.

messages.title: More Police on the Beat with Labour
messages.content: Cynon Valley candidate Ann Clwyd welcomes Labour Leader, Jeremy Corbyn's commitment to active roles for Wales. 'This means we will promote policing in Cynon Valley,' she wrote, promising more bobby’s to patrol our streets. The Labour party will replace funding cut short after Dillon, promote intelligence to prevent crime as well as welfare cuts that are impacting.
